metadata.titleEn: Aerosol Optical Property Dataset of Tibetan Plateau by ground-based observation (2021)
metadata.description: The ground-based observation dataset of aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau was obtained by continuous observation with a Cimel 318  sunphotometer, involving two stations: Qomolangma Station and Nam Co Station. These products have taken the process  of cloud detection. The data cover the period from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021, and the time resolution is daily. The sunphotometer has eight observation channels from visible light to near infrared, and the central wavelengths are 340, 380, 440, 500, 670, 870, 940 and 1120 nm, respectively. The field of view angle of the instrument is 1.2°, and the sun tracking accuracy is 0.1°. Six bands of aerosol optical thickness can be obtained from direct solar radiation, and the accuracy is estimated to be 0.01-0.02. Finally, AERONET unified inversion algorithm was used to obtain the aerosol optical thickness, Ångström index, aerosol particle size distribution, single scattering albedo, phase function, complex refraction index and asymmetry factor.
metadata.instructions: The AOD dataset is stored in text format, and the file name is "yymmdd.txt", where yy stands for year, mm stands for month, dd stands for date. For example, 210101.txt represents this ASCII file describing the AOD information on the Tibetan Plateau on the first day of January 2021.

background: The Tibetan Plateau (TP) is one of the most imposing topographic features on the surface of the Earth. With an immense area (about 2,500,000 km2) and mean elevation of more than 4000 m above sea level, TP plays a key role in Asia climatology and atmospheric circulation. Meanwhile, the atmosphere over the plateau is probably the least affected by human activities in the Asian continent due to the sparse population and minimal industries, providing a unique opportunity to describe atmospheric processes and changes. In this context, several model simulation and satellite observation works have been carried out over the TP to elucidate the effects of aerosol on regional climate and water cycles. However, ground-based optical characterizations of aerosols are scarce at TP. Considering its huge area and essential role in the climate system, the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over TP leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments. AERONET (Aerosol Robotic Network) is a worldwide aerosol characterization network with the automatic CIMEL Sun/sky radiometer as the principal instrument. Due to its significant advances on observation techniques and analysis methods, AERONET has been producing reliably and continuously detailed optical properties of various types of aerosols worldwide.
research objective: This paper will focus on the optical properties (AOD, Angstrom parameter) and volume size distribution of aerosols in this poorly understood region based on the first-year (Aug 2006–Jul 2007) AERONET data. We expect such information can help to understand the atmosphere condition and interactive processes over the TP, validate the product of satellite measurements, and improve the initialization for climate models involving TP and the surrounding regions.
challenges: Considering its huge area and essential role in the climate system, the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties over TP leads to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments.
methods: At Nam Co station, a TSP sampler was also set up and collected aerosol samples weekly during the AERONET observation (Cong et al., 2007). In order to determine the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types, twelve TSP samples (monthly) were also analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, PHILIPS XL 30 FEG) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX). Measurements of aerosol optical properties were made with AERONET sun/sky radiometers at the Nam Co Station, a remote high elevation site in central TP from August 2006 to July 2007.
dataset: In August 2006, an automatic sun and sky scanning radiometer (CIMEL) was established at Nam Co, central Tibetan Plateau as an AERONET site.
findings: Predominant daily measurements of AOD (N95%) at Nam Co Station below the background level (τa 500 nm b0.1), representing one of the most pristine site in the AERONET network. It was also found the AOD produced by AREONET measurement in this study (annual mean value 0.05) is significantly lower than simultaneous MODIS observation. This work could enhance our knowledge on the aerosol distribution over the TP and helpful for the modeling of climate change and validation of satellite remote sensing products.

Definition.Question: What is the role of a sun/sky radiometer in the collection of aerosol optical thickness data?
Definition.Answer: A sun/sky radiometer, such as the CIMEL 318, is used for continuous observation of aerosols to obtain data on aerosol optical thickness (AOD) by measuring direct solar radiation across multiple wavelengths. The instrument's precision in solar tracking and its ability to operate in different spectral bands make it crucial for accurately determining AOD and related aerosol properties.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The challenges in measuring aerosol optical properties over the Tibetan Plateau include its vast area, its essential role in the climate system, and the scarcity of ground-based observations. These factors contribute to uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments, making it difficult to obtain detailed knowledge of aerosol characteristics in this region.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced in aerosol optical property data collection on the Tibetan Plateau differ from those encountered in other regions with dense populations and industrial activities?
Comparison.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau, being sparsely populated with minimal industrial influence, offers a unique environment for aerosol studies, presenting challenges primarily in terms of accessibility and the lack of ground-based optical characterizations, whereas regions with dense populations and industrial activities might face challenges related to pollution interference and data variability due to anthropogenic factors.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of ground-based observational instruments like the sun/sky radiometer in capturing aerosol optical properties in remote regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Ground-based observational instruments such as the sun/sky radiometer, specifically CIMEL as used in the AERONET network, are effective in capturing detailed aerosol optical properties in remote regions like the Tibetan Plateau. These instruments allow for continuous and reliable measurements of aerosol optical depth (AOD) and other properties, providing data that is necessary for understanding regional atmospheric conditions and validating satellite measurements.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges in measuring aerosol optical properties over large, sparsely populated areas affect the accuracy of climate models?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in measuring aerosol optical properties over large, sparsely populated areas like the Tibetan Plateau lead to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments. The lack of detailed ground-based measurements contributes to these uncertainties, emphasizing the importance of networks like AERONET for improving the accuracy of climate models and understanding atmospheric processes in such regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the preference for utilizing AERONET sun/sky radiometers in aerosol optical property measurement on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: AERONET is chosen for its significant advances in observation techniques and analysis methods, which have allowed it to produce reliably and continuously detailed optical properties of various types of aerosols worldwide, making it suitable for the poorly understood region of the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using sun/sky radiometers and SEM-EDX techniques for collecting aerosol data in remote high-altitude areas like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using sun/sky radiometers and SEM-EDX techniques allows for detailed characterization of aerosol optical properties and types, providing insights into atmospheric processes in remote regions. This can lead to improved climate modeling and validation of satellite products, although the lack of comprehensive ground-based data could still result in uncertainties.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the absence of detailed aerosol optical properties data on the Tibetan Plateau impact climate modeling and assessments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The absence of detailed aerosol optical properties data can lead to significant uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments. This lack of data hinders the validation of satellite measurements and limits the understanding of atmospheric conditions and interactive processes over the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of finding significantly lower AOD values from ground-based measurements compared to satellite observations in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Finding lower AOD values from ground-based measurements compared to satellite observations could indicate discrepancies in data that may affect the accuracy of satellite products. This can prompt further investigations into measurement techniques and enhance understanding of aerosol distribution, ultimately aiding in more accurate climate modeling and remote sensing validation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of collecting aerosol optical thickness (AOD) data over the Tibetan Plateau using ground-based sun photometers?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals include understanding the atmosphere condition and interactive processes over the Tibetan Plateau, validating satellite measurement products, and improving climate model initialization for the region, given its essential role in the climate system and the lack of detailed knowledge of aerosol optical properties.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are served by using techniques like scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) in aerosol sample analysis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: These techniques aim to determine the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types, thereby providing detailed characterization of aerosols, which is crucial for accurately modeling their effects on climate and validating remote sensing data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in using Cimel 318 sun photometers for the collection of aerosol optical thickness data over high-altitude regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Cimel 318 sun photometer is used for continuous observation, employing eight channels with specific wavelengths from the visible to near-infrared range. The instrument features a field of view of 1.2° and a solar tracking accuracy of 0.1°. Data collection occurs daily and requires cloud detection for data validation, followed by processing with a unified inversion algorithm to derive aerosol optical thickness and other properties.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are aerosol samples collected and analyzed to determine different types of aerosols in remote high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A TSP (Total Suspended Particulate) sampler is set up to collect aerosol samples on a weekly basis. In addition, monthly samples are further analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDX) to determine the occurrence and percentage of different aerosol types.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the use of sun/sky radiometers in collecting aerosol optical thickness data in remote high-elevation sites?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the CIMEL 318 sun/sky radiometer, which provides automated and precise measurements with a sun tracking accuracy of 0.1° and a field of view of 1.2°, enable the collection of aerosol optical thickness data in remote high-elevation sites like those in the Tibetan Plateau.

Enablement.Question: How do cloud detection algorithms enhance the accuracy of aerosol optical thickness measurements in meteorologically complex regions?
Enablement.Answer: Cloud detection algorithms enhance the accuracy of aerosol optical thickness measurements by filtering out cloud-contaminated data, ensuring that only clear-sky observations are used in the analysis, as seen in the dataset collected over the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: What expectations exist for the use of ground-based optical characterizations of aerosols in improving climate models involving the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Ground-based optical characterizations of aerosols, such as those provided by AERONET, are expected to validate satellite measurements and improve the initialization of climate models. This can lead to a better understanding of atmospheric conditions and interactive processes over the Tibetan Plateau, which are currently poorly understood.

Expectation.Question: What reasons might account for the anticipated differences between ground-based AERONET measurements and satellite observations of aerosol optical depth at the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The AERONET measurements at the Tibetan Plateau have shown significantly lower annual mean AOD values compared to satellite observations like MODIS. This discrepancy might be due to the pristine conditions of the site and the precision of ground-based instruments, which might capture lower AOD levels that satellites might not detect accurately due to their broader spatial coverage and different measurement techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What are the principal challenges faced in collecting aerosol optical data in remote and high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau, and how might these challenges impact the development of comprehensive datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Principal challenges include the sparse population and minimal industrial activities leading to fewer ground-based observation sites. These factors, combined with the vast area and essential climate role of the Tibetan Plateau, can lead to large uncertainties in climate modeling and assessments, impacting the comprehensiveness of datasets by limiting the amount of detailed ground-based optical data available.
